p: Costa et al. (2013) [ 21] conducted studies with the essential oils of the species Annona pickelii (Diels) H. Rainer and Annona salzmannii A. DC., which presented in vitro anti- T. cruzi activity of 28.7 and 89.7 µg/mL, respectively. In 2012, Costa et al. [ 32] conducted a study on Annona vepretorum Mart., which presented trypanocidal activity against T. cruzi at a concentration of 40.9 µg/mL. Analysis of the essential oils of these species revealed that sesquiterpenes are the main constituents; for Annona pickelii, the highest percentages were for bicyclogermacrene and ( E)-caryophyllene; for A. salzmannii, the compounds with the highest percentages were ( E)-caryophyllene, bicyclogermacrene, δ-cadinene, α-copaene and germacrene D; and for Annona vepretorum, the compounds with the highest percentages were bicyclogermacrene and spathulenol. In general, the trypanocidal activities were attributed to the high concentrations of bicyclogermacrene.
